At Thu, 12 Jul 2007 23:24:05 +0000,
"Eric J. Bowman" <eric@...> wrote:
>
> [Julian? wrote]
> >
> >So what if there is a proxy that doesn't even forward the second DELETE
> >because it already knows about the previous DELETE? Or if the
> >XmlHttpRequest object follows the spec and assumes that if a GET/HEAD on
> >a resource once returned a 410, it doesn't make sense to access that URI
> >again?
> >
>
> I don't believe every HTTP client in existence is broken.  Point any web
> browser, on any platform, at a 410 response.  Now, hit "reload".  See?
> The reload button is still available, and the client will indeed repeat
> the request.  Every time.  4xx responses are not cacheable because they
> do not indicate permanence.

The fact that *at the moment* web browsers do not take into account
the difference between a 404 & 410 and reload a 410 is irrelevant.
Would you consider it an error if a browser saved a little bandwidth
and didn’t really reload a 410? I wouldn’t. A browser trusts the
server. If a server sends a 410, it means it. As an example, browsers
issue conditional GETs when reloading: in other words, they trust the
server to send them the new representation if it’s actually new. Do
you consider this an error?

Additionally, if a HEAD returns 410, why should a software client be
expected to believe that a DELETE might have any meaningful effect on
that resource?

best,
Erik Hetzner
;; Erik Hetzner, California Digital Library
;; gnupg key id: 1024D/01DB07E3
